INPUT.NAME: NFS_SERVER_NETWORK
INPUT.DESCRIPTION: Which target should be allowed to connect
INPUT.LONGDESCRIPTION: You can input either a hostname, an IP or an IP network and a mask (eg. 192.168.1.0/24)

SELECT1.NAME: NFS_SERVER_SECURE
SELECT1.DESCRIPTION: Should the usage of a reserved port be enforced

SELECT1.NAME: NFS_SERVER_READWRITE
SELECT1.DESCRIPTION: Which access policy do you want to apply

SELECT1.NAME: NFS_SERVER_SYNC
SELECT1.DESCRIPTION: Which writing policy do you want to apply
SELECT1.LONGDESCRIPTION: Synchronized mode is advised for a safe usage and is the default, Asynchronized mode is mainly used if performance is required over all (This violates the plain NFS protocol and might not be compatible with all implementations)

SELECT1.NAME: NFS_SERVER_WDELAY
SELECT1.DESCRIPTION: If synchronized, do you want to optimize the writing by grouping the requests
SELECT1.LONGDESCRIPTION: This is generally safe, but might tamper with performance if a lot of tiny independant requests are made

SELECT1.NAME: NFS_SERVER_HIDE
SELECT1.DESCRIPTION: Should a nested filesystem be accessible to the client
SELECT1.LONGDESCRIPTION: This is a little trick that should normally not be used (might create inode conflicts and be incompatible with some NFS implementations)

SELECT1.NAME: NFS_SERVER_SUBTREECHECK
SELECT1.DESCRIPTION: Do you need a strict security checking on every access
SELECT1.LONGDESCRIPTION: Normally, NFS won't do a strict checking on subdirectories for performance (especially on home directories), but you might want to enable this on other cases

SELECT1.NAME: NFS_SERVER_SECURELOCKS
SELECT1.DESCRIPTION: Do you want to require authentication for every lock request
SELECT1.LONGDESCRIPTION: This is enabled by default, but might not be desired with old NFS clients

SELECT1.NAME: NFS_SERVER_ACL
SELECT1.DESCRIPTION: Should the filesystem ACLs be exposed through NFS
SELECT1.LONGDESCRIPTION: This is enabled by default, you might want to disable it on old NFS clients
